thread.title: 7 things to know today, plus why Orlando may be most lucrative stop for All Aboard Florida
thread.title_full: 7 things to know today, plus why Orlando may be most lucrative stop for All Aboard Florida

author: Cindy Barth
title: 7 things to know today, plus why Orlando may be most lucrative stop for All Aboard Florida
text: 7 things to know today, plus why Orlando may be most lucrative stop for All Aboard Florida Jul 13, 2015, 6:46am EDT Updated All Aboard Florida Illustration of the planned $1.5 billion, 235-mile All Aboard Florida Orlando-to-Miami… more Even though South Florida will have three All Aboard Florida stations open long before Orlando comes into the picture, a new study shows that the City Beautiful's leg of the 235-mile system should be the most lucrative, the Orlando Sentinel reports. According to the ridership study commissioned by All Aboard Florida, Orlando's part of the train system is expected to attract 2.5 million passengers paying about $90 each by 2020 — or more than $229 million in annual fares. The Miami, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach stations, meanwhile, are expected to bring in a combined $64 million annually. Home of the Day And be sure to check out these other Monday headlines: Marriott Vacation Club adds iconic D.C. location Orlando-based Marriott Vacation Club , a global leader in vacation ownership, purchased 71 rooms in The Mayflower Hotel in Washington, D.C., and plans to make them part of its Marriott Vacation Club vacation ownership program. The Mayflower Hotel is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and has enjoyed several U.S. presidents and countless world leaders and dignitaries as guests. "This is simply an amazing property with so much history and character," said Stephen P. Weisz , president and chief executive officer of Marriott Vacations Worldwide . Owners will have access to the renowned property beginning Aug. 1, The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Embry-Riddle earns kudos for aviation safety program Congratulations to Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University , whose flight training department became the first flight training organization in the nation to complete stage 1 registration of the International Standard for Business Aircraft Operations, a rigorous auditing process that evaluates an organization's safety management system. Read more here . Dixon Ticonderoga adding 20 jobs Writing instruments and art supplies manufacturer Dixon Ticonderoga Co. announced July 10 that it will expand its Central Florida headquarters in Lake Mary with the addition of 20 new jobs and a capital investment of $1.5 million over the next three years. The Lake Mary-based company landed a tax incentive deal with Seminole County in March to lease a new facility and create the 20 jobs. Read more here . OBJ seeking nominations for Veterans of Influence Orlando Business Journal is seeking nominations for the Veterans of Influence Awards now through July 31. The program will recognize military veterans who have made a significant achievement in their careers in the past year, have a strong record of innovation or outstanding performance in their work and are actively involved in our community. We also plan to give a special American Eagle award. To nominate someone, click here . Trending this morning on Google Business
